text: I'm Gavin Sherlock I'm an associate
professor in genetics at Stanford
University I went to the University of
Manchester to study genetics as an
undergraduate uh I then stayed in
Manchester to do a PhD in molecular
biology the best research was really
being carried out in the US so I came to
the US to do a postar at Cold Spring
Harbor my lab primarily uh looks at the
process of evolution and what we've done
over the last uh probably six or seven
years is develop ever more uh specific
and high resolution systems with uh
which we can uh interrogate the process
of evolution itself one of the main
things that I enjoy about teaching is
that it tells you whether you actually
understand something properly yourself
so when you have to generate the content
it forces you to to deeply understand
that content first which I think makes
you a better scientist what I'm
passionate about is what genomics allows
me to do um the rate at which the
ability to interrogate a biological
system is increasing as well as the
diversity of ways in which that system
might be interrogated has allowed uh us
as well as others in the field to ask
questions that literally a decade ago
were inconceivable to even be able to
ask and that's why I think is exciting
